captions.text: [THEME MUSIC PLAYING]

[MUSIC - PUNK COVER OF "WHEN
THE SAINTS GO MARCHING IN"]

MIKE PRICHINELLO: We started off
by going through all the

cars we had as kids on our
walls, posters, right.

So that was a good starting
place, things like the AC

Shelby Cobra, '67 Chevelle,
911s, we got through those
pretty quickly.
308 Ferraris, 328 Ferraris.

ZAC MOSELEY: We also made
our share of mistakes.

MIKE PRICHINELLO:
Yeah, we did.

What was our very,
very first car?
ZAC MOSELEY: The Aston V8.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: Oh,
the Aston Martin.

Yeah, OK, so this is
a good example.

Aston Martin 77 V8, epic car, it
looked like American muscle

in the front, European
business in the rear.

Had a really good
exhaust note.

Everything about it was cool,
it just never worked.
Basically, it would go out.

We'd take apart, put it back
together so the next member
could drive.

MIKE G: It was just an older
car that we couldn't figure
out what was going on with it.

My predecessor, the guy before
me, had taken one of the heads

apart and figured, OK,
this is what it is.

But unfortunately, he didn't
adjust any of the valves.

I ended up having to redo all of
the valve lashes, redo all

of the timing, and
resync the carbs.

Finally got the thing running
after like three years just

[BLEEP]ing around with it,
got the thing running.

And as soon as I got it running,
they got rid of it.

ZAC MOSELEY: We're at
this place called
The Classic Car Club.

I'm Zac Moseley, and this is
Mike Prichinello, we run it.

We have a fleet of cars, about
40 some odd of them, ranging

from '60s American muscles
to brand new exotic cars.

And our job is to keep them on
the road and get members

behind the wheel and deliver
awesome automotive
experiences.
Right?
MIKE PRICHINELLO: Yeah.

We actually do keep all 40
something cars on the road.

It's not too often you see
something like this.
Actually, that's not true.

You see this all the time, but
it doesn't last very long.

ZAC MOSELEY: Yeah, people walk
in all the time and say, how

do you keep these
things going?

It's pretty simple, if you
get to drive them.

You can get the best car out
there, show-winning trophy

car, and you drive it 10 miles,
then it breaks down
because it never get driven.

Everything is dried up and
not working, so you've
got to drive it.

You have to exercise mechanical
sympathy.

Mike and I could get in to this
Shelby Cobra running on

three cylinders with no clutch
and drive 400 or 500 miles on
it, and get there.

Because we were meant to race
Le Mans in the '50s.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: [INAUDIBLE]
the side of the road.

ZAC MOSELEY: We know how to
nurse the thing into the pits.

But we could hand the key 100%
totally running to someone who

doesn't know what they're doing,
and they could blow it
up before the first stoplight.

So you just have to feel the
car and sympathize with it.

Every time you step on the gas
pedal, there's thousands of

moving parts capturing a chaotic
explosion and turning
it to kinetic motion.

And you have to have some
appreciation for that.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: Yeah, just
because an old car has an

8,000 red line, doesn't
mean you should bring
it to 8,000, right?

It's just a line on a gauge,
right, like have a little
sympathy in your foot.

Sort of feel out how much
your car can handle.

ZAC MOSELEY: And then the
other stuff is basic
maintenance.

Every car we get in here, we put
out on the lift for four

weeks and go through everything
and drive it.

And Mike and I try to break it
just to see what else is on

its way out, and replace it, and
get ahead of the curve on
all that stuff.

MIKE G: My name is Mike G, I
take care of all the cars here
at Classic Car Club.

The best thing about working
here versus just your typical

shop is it's not a rush to get
the car done, it's a passion
to get it right.

Because we're going to have any
one of 300 plus different
guys with lead feet.

You don't want to be able to get
into it and find a lot of
stuff broken.

You want to be able to get
into it and everything is
where it should be.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: You gotta add
a bit of modern equipment
to an old car.

You drive modern day cars, and
you expect them to stop in
this distance.

Things like brake boosters are
really important, putting
power brakes when we can.

If something happens to have
drum brakes, we put in some

disc brakes, just to
keep people safe.

We like to make things go
faster, actually, as long as
they'll stop quicker.

So Zac will always do some
kind of work on cars.

A lot of the old cars we'll do
like custom headers, custom

exhausts, let them breathe
a little better,
make them sound better.

ZAC MOSELEY: Cooling systems,
you know it's number one.

Number one thing that old
cars do is overheat.

So put a big aluminum radiator
and an electric fan in.
Make them more usable.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: Everybody
loves an iPod
adapter, gotta do that.

But, yeah, it's all about making
them run more like

people think they're
going to run.

I use this analogy a lot, where
I heard the guys from

KISS talk about their reunion
tour, and they're like, oh

man, we had to do these
fireworks and all this stuff

because that's how people
remembered our shows in the

'70s, even though they weren't
like that at all.

But you've got to live
up to what people
thought things were like.

People think of '67 Chevelles
as just like a grenade of
energy down the street.

But we had to create all of our
cars to be what they think
they're supposed to be like.
And that's a lot of work.

ZAC MOSELEY: The rest
is pretty simple.

The more interesting part is the
heroic recoveries when it
does go wrong.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: In 2006, I
think, we drove from New York

to Miami on all the
back roads.

And we were in the Blue
Mountains, Blue Ridge Mountain

Parkway, which is a really
great driving road.

And there was a bit of
a gaggle of Porsches.

I was in a GT3, and there was I
think three others with us.

Actually this, was the
trip to New Orleans.

ZAC MOSELEY: I was setting the
pace in the Mini Cooper S.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: Mini Cooper
S that we brought to Helix.

Yeah, and it was
a bit suped up.

But still, it was a Mini
Cooper amongst
GTs, GT3s and stuff.

And it was the middle of
the night, and Zac hit
a rock in the road.

ZAC MOSELEY: It was like, I saw
it, and I kind of zigged
and then zagged.

And bam, right in the
middle of the wheel.

And the wheel was round
like this, and it had
this fold like this.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: We're like
in the mountains where they

make moonshine and
kill people.

ZAC MOSELEY: So we had AAA on
the phone, they're like what's
your cross street?
And we're like--

MIKE PRICHINELLO: There
is no cross street.

ZAC MOSELEY: I don't know, I saw
mile marker like 120 a few
miles back.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: So now it's
getting dark, and it's
starting to rain.
And the only light is thunder.

Or lightning I guess would
be the light part of it.
So Zac got the wheel off.

We ditched him because we
had to get to the bar.

And so we left him on the
mountain, and Zac with a

hammer, grass, and duct tape,
got that car off [INAUDIBLE].

ZAC MOSELEY: We were
bending it back--

it hadn't cracked-- and we
were bending it back, and

we're like, oh we can almost
get it to hold air.

And just got it just
about ready to hold
air, the last whack.

And so it crack, it cracked and
a chunk fell out of it,

and it was like oh
no, it's over.

Then I had to get up and duct
tape, stuff it with hay, and I
drove down the mountain.
It was pretty rough.
It was like, [BUMPING NOISES].

MIKE PRICHINELLO:
It was 20 miles.
Yeah I know, but we made it.
We made it all the way down.

I always say have a fire
extinguisher in your car.

It looks pretty bitchin', you
know, if you mount it like in
the center column there there.
It's actually good to have.

ZAC MOSELEY: Because you don't
want to be that dude with his

brand new Lamborghini, standing
there with his arms

folded, watching it to
burn to the ground.

If there's a little fire,
and you can put it
out, save your car.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: That's
not the way
to wind up on Jalopnik.
Be like the next [INAUDIBLE].

This car lit on fire,
actually.

It happens to all the
best of them.

ZAC MOSELEY: This one's
intelligent, though, it went
on fire in the wash bay.

Literally, we finished washing
it, started it up, boom.

But we had a hose there,
put it out.

Burned up the air box
and the air filter.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: So have
a fire extinguisher.

That's rule number one on
the side of the road.

Rule number two is, get off the
road if you're actually
losing power.

You have to actually
get off the road.

Don't be that dude in the right
lane who broke down on a

bridge because he wasn't
planning it out.

And everybody's got
to sit in traffic.
ZAC MOSELEY: I've done that.
MIKE PRICHINELLO: [LAUGHING]
He's done that, actually.

ZAC MOSELEY: Uphill on the
Williamsburg Bridge the fuel
pump went on the Jag.

And I could feel just as
I got on the bridge.

And there was a point
of no return.

Heard a little sputter,
and then it kind of
sputtered some more.

And I'm like, come on, foot
down, let's go, let's just get
to the top of the crest.

And I can see it coming,
and then it died.

And it started rolling backwards
on the bridge.

I just had to wait while traffic
stacked up behind me,

it was like Sunday evening,
it was a disaster.
MIKE PRICHINELLO: E Type Jag.

That is like the quintessential
classic car
club car, right? '68, '69.

Anybody will tell you that a
Series 1 is the prettiest.

It's got the covered headlights,
the grille opening

is a little smaller, it's a bit
more of like a feminine
look to it.

And then the Two got a little
bigger, and then the Three was
a 12 cylinder.
They're all very beautiful.

If you put them all next to each
other, you'd probably go
for the first one, Series 1.

But it never worked, it always
overheated because of that

little opening in the front, not
enough air got in there.

The key to owning an old
Jag is throw away
the original motor.
That's what we did.

ZAC MOSELEY: When it came time
to rebuild the original E Type

motor, it's about $10,000 give
or take by the time you go

through a motor, and
you have to change
everything around it.

This is a Series Three XJ6 motor
they made until 1987
with the same architecture.

It's gotta be the longest
running basic
engine design of anything.

They made it for
like 40 years.

And the carbon exhaust manifold
and the original oil

pin bolt right onto
this XJ6 block.

It's basically, we have a
disposable motor now.

You can buy a whole running XJ6
for about $1,800, or pull
a running motor for $400.

And it has a better cooling
and oiling system, it's

modernized, it's
more powerful.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: Also
buy the year that--

not the year that everybody
wants, but the next one that
everybody is going to want.

I'd never say buy a classic car
as an investment, because

you're just gonna spend a ton of
cash on it, and it's really

never going to be a good
investment for you.

But with that said, you should
at least sort of know what the

next one is, right, so you're
not so far underwater.

So everybody wants a '73
RS Porsche, right?

That's the one, it's
$400,000 now.

But the 964 RS America, you
could get for like $45,000.

And I think that's a sleeper
car, I think that that's a
really, really cool car.

It's kind of better than the
first one, and it costs 1/10

of the price in Classic Car Club
math, which is appalling,

but I think right
in that case.

ZAC MOSELEY: And it's going to
be mechanically stronger.

It's a more modern car, you
can actually drive it.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: We got
a 328 over there.

There's yards and
yards of [BLEEP]
you could talk about that car.

ZAC MOSELEY: That's the car that
you'd make the decision

to buy based on complete
nostalgia.

So you've been working hard,
to you're a hardworking

journalist at Jalopnik, and you
just bought yourself a new

Honda Civic that's
about $26,000.

And you say, oh man,
a 308 Ferrari.
I saw one for $24,000.

Maybe I can get that instead
of my Civic.
Don't do it.

I will say, these 328s,
especially, are pretty good
work horses as far as they go.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: They're better
than new Ferraris.

ZAC MOSELEY: They're pretty
strong in Ferrari terms, the
parts are pretty reasonable.

But still like a clutch disc is
$800, and it needs a major

service every 30,000 miles or
three years, or 15,000 miles

or 3 years, that you have to
take the old engine out.

Change all the seals,
everything, and the parts for

that are about $2,500, the
labor is probably $4,000.

And then they're going to find
about $10,000 of other [BLEEP]

that's wrong with
your Ferrari.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: But I
still do love them.

It's a funny thing, my
enthusiasm for cars has not
waned whatsoever.

But I just try to be more
practical about them now.

MIKE G: This is actually one of
the nine original cars that
we had here.

It was from Backdraft, and we
beat it up so much that it
became their test car.

They actually changed a lot of
modifications on the car, just

because of what they had
gone through with us.

It's just a simple car, it's
something that there's not a

lot of computer with it, there's
no ABS, there's no

electronic crap that you have to
deal with with most of the
newer cars.

It is just a basic original
motor, tranny, drive gear.

Lights on and off, it doesn't
even have a radio in it.
It's pretty fun to work on.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: Oh, I
would love to have a
French car in the fleet.

In our London fleet, we
have an old Citroen--
DS12?
Is that right?

Anyway, really cool, they
make that noise,
[IMITATES QUIET MOTOR NOISE]

as they drive by with the air
ride and all that stuff.

And I would like to have
one here, but there
are no parts here.

So in England, it makes a lot
more sense, it could not run
there efficiently.

Here it could not run
inefficiently.

ZAC MOSELEY: Jensen
Interceptor.

The London Club had one, and
it was the best looking car

they ever owned, because
it never turned
a mile on the road.
Didn't have a rock chip on it.
It was like perfectly glossy.

But every time they went to
start it, the British

electronics would fight with the
American motor, and like

the Italian interior would
light on fire.
It was crazy.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: This is a
category that I never buy.
Never buy Frankenstein cars.

By that I mean, cars made by two
different manufacturers.

So that car, American drive
train, English body, English

electronics, that
never worked.

We had a Pantera, Detomaso
Pantera, very, very cool,
Italian body.

See you're already in
for some trouble.

351 Cleveland in it, American
power plant.

Once you start doing those
things, once countries get

together to make something
stupendous, it never happens.

I'll tell you, so having owned
hundreds of cars in New York
City, it's not an easy place.

As an individual, you don't
really get a parking garage,
you just get a spot.

And old cars need garages
because old cars need tools,
and old cars need maintenance.

And so you can't just go
to 18th Street parking
garage and have that.
It's a really difficult thing.

It's one of the reasons why the
Classic Car Club makes a
lot of sense in New York.
There's also the roads.

Traffic's not as bad as people
make it out to be
in New York, actually.

Compared to most cities, we
don't have it too bad.

We do have swimming pool
sized potholes.
Cobblestones.

Not the smoothest road we
could have driven down.

So you've gotta learn
that a bit.

So having a car of any sort of
consequence, a supercar or a

classic car, you're going to
go through your set of

[INAUDIBLE], you're going to
replace your bushings more

often than other places just
to keep it all tight.
And we do that all here.

But at the same time, you know
what's cool about it?

Let's say you take a convertible
through Midtown,

and you're driving through all
the skyscrapers, and you get

to see a side of New York you
really don't see when you're
walking around or whatever.

We've had a lot of fun
in cars, actually.

One time we had our old '68 911
out that had this ragingly

loud exhaust, and like a big
Le Mans style wheel.

And Zac and I were hysterical
laughing all through side
streets of New York.

It was echoing through
the buildings, that
was a lot of fun.

We've spent seven years finding
really good roads, and

we've tested every car possible
in every kind of

environment from traffic in
Midtown to full out on the

highways, to country
backroads.
There's a lot of places to go.

For me, driving classic cars
is a really cool time to
actually sort of go slow.

I'm always into driving fast,
and being on the track, and

being in really competitive
cars.

But driving something like an
old E Type Jag, it just kind
of slows things down a bit.

I actually really
like doing it.

I forget how much I like doing
it until I'm in one.

ZAC MOSELEY: We had a 308 Dino,
which actually you guys

were bugging me about when I
kept dropping the price,

dropping the price trying
to sell it.

Because it was rusting through
every corner of the car, it
was just gonna fall apart.
But--

MIKE PRICHINELLO: And
it's a bit unloved.
ZAC MOSELEY: Yeah.

When it first showed up, Mike
and I got in, and Mike started

driving, and the steering wheel
was over there, and his
feet were over the other side.

The gear shift is all grindy,
but it made this kind of great
popping sound.

It was running really rich, but
it came off gas like bah
bah bah bah bah.

And we just drove from here to
14th Street, we were laughing
the whole way.
It was awesome, [INAUDIBLE].

MIKE PRICHINELLO: Big grins
and bleeding eyes.

Because it was just so much
gasoline smell coming through

the car, but it was
a lot of fun.

ZAC MOSELEY: And you wouldn't
get that in a new BMW.

You'd just be bored, listening
to NPR and driving up Hudson.
Come on.
Turn green.

ZAC MOSELEY: I'd say probably
one of my most favorite heroic

saves of a car is the Mustang,
actually, the
white one back there.

We put a five speed
gearbox in.

And it had a cable clutch
originally that went right

through the header, so the thing
was just bound to melt.

Someone was coming back
in traffic and melted

[INAUDIBLE], and eventually
the cable broke.

And he called me just like
stuck, and it was the day of
the gay pride parade.

And he wasn't far, he
was on 14th Street.

So I'm like, alright, let me
come get the car off you, and

you can go where you have to go,
and we'll figure it out.

And I got there, and I'm
thinking, can anyone come tow

me, what am I going to do,
it's Sunday afternoon.

And I'm like, I can get it
back, so I just put it in

first, turned the key, bump
started off the starter, and

just sort of matched shifts
all the way through.

But then I came across
Christopher Street, there's
some people [INAUDIBLE]

coming across, I'm like alright,
you guys gotta get

out of my way, because I have no
clutch, I'm not gonna stop.

As soon as the light goes green,
I'm hitting the starter
again, popping off.

MIKE PRICHINELLO: You
couldn't even get it
into neutral, right?

ZAC MOSELEY: No, what I would do
is I'd pull it in neutral,

coast to a stop, and then
shut the car off,
put it back in gear.

And as soon as the light
went green, bump it.

But people were still doing the
late cross, I'm like, you

don't want to do that in front
of me, because I'm gonna
launch right into you.

Because you kind of had to go
for it, you had to lurch, and

then get on the gas to
keep it all going.

I managed not to collect
any people.
MIKE PRICHINELLO: Collect.

That's a really nice way
to say kill, collect.

ZAC MOSELEY: Yeah, it looked
like I was trying to terrorize
gay people.

I love gay people, don't
get me wrong.

But I wasn't trying to run
you over, I'm sorry.

I was just trying to get
home in one piece.

title: How To Drive Classic Cars Every Day -- JALOPNIK ON /DRIVE

comments.text:
Most of the problem with these cars is they need the open road. That is 
what they were designed for, not to be choked to death in bumper to bumper 
slow traffic.﻿
comments.author: 57WillysCJ

comments.text: I miss videos like this in Drive﻿
comments.author: S Miller

comments.text:
Man but who wants to drive great cars around in traffic, on flatland, with 
no open spaces.  I'm sure the 5 Burroughs are a great market for this shit 
but there are no roads worth driving till you get out to the parkways 
around Chappiqua.  A place like Denver or San-fran with foothills and legit 
mountains would be a better fit.﻿
comments.author: piecartbox

comments.text: No 2CVs?﻿
comments.author: Leif Vejby

comments.text:
Wait, is there a guy walking an actual CHIMP over that crosswalk at 15:09 ? 
Or is this just a kid that walks silly?﻿
comments.author: Christian Lang (MasterTRL)

comments.text:
Funny how they dis on mixing american mechanics with european bodies and 
then talk almost most of the show about a cobra...﻿
comments.author: nicolas mallo

comments.text: I like their approach to classic cars. Like a Singer 911. :) ﻿
comments.author: Anderson C

comments.text:
If frankenstein cars didn't make any sense, then why does everybody and 
their dog throw 2JZs or LS1s in just about any car...? ﻿
comments.author: Thomas Lee

comments.text:
HELP, Each month I come to Manhattan for work, and month after month I walk 
past my 1995 993 and my 2011 997.2 and get in my safe C 300 to drive into 
the city. I have no idea where to park my 911's in NYC. I want to know is 
their self parking in the city where I can leave the Porsche over night and 
come back the next day to see it how I left it? Big thanks!! ﻿
comments.author: Stephen Cherry

comments.text:
i wonder what they'd say about my '79 camaro i'm restoring right now? i'm 
19 so its kind of a budget hot rod build :) got 'bout 4000 bucks on it 
still need 2... im not quitting, i love it!﻿
comments.author: justrockon426

comments.text: +GreenJeep1998 mostly babes, thats the most ;)
comments.author: justrockon426

comments.text: +justrockon426 sounds like it'll be fun!
comments.author: GreenJeep1998

comments.text:
with 300 horses, the 700r4 tranny and a 373 locking differential in the 
rear, i hope i can enjoy it and exchange rides for cash, ass or beer XD
comments.author: justrockon426

comments.text:
'How To Drive Classic Cars Every Day - No need to explain it to me. I've 
seen both versions of Gone in 60 Seconds.﻿
comments.author: David Stout

comments.text:
yeah, thats more like how to need 2 cars to last one day! - the first gone 
in 60 seconds.
comments.author: justrockon426

comments.text: He said he loves gay people. That's pretty gay.﻿
comments.author: peter john kattz

comments.text:
I once was that guy on the bridge. I had bought a new fuel filter and it 
was sitting right on the passenger seat because I hadn't gotten around to 
changing it. Leaving the toll booth heading up the bridge, the bowl on the 
carb emptied. I was left with a trickle of fuel that kept me sputtering 
along at about 25 mph as people swerved around me. I rejoiced as I got over 
the crest and started picking up speed. Once off the bridge, I pulled over 
to let the carb fill up and a guy pulled up behind me and was shouting my 
car was on fire. Running the car that lean heated up the cat and ignited 
the oil splattered on it. We got the fire out by kicking dirt on it, but a 
fire extinguisher would have been real nice right about then :)﻿
comments.author: parnelli jones

comments.text: 1970 chevelle ﻿
comments.author: Iphone Gameplay

comments.text: Should have bought that 964 RS America when you said to back in 2012!﻿
comments.author: Joseph Muench

comments.text:
In America do you just have red and green for your lights? Here in the UK 
we have a orange as a warning it's going to change.﻿
comments.author: Mr English

comments.text: +justrockon426 ''yellow
comments.author: justrockon426

comments.text: +Dineth J we even got orange lights in canada dude...
comments.author: justrockon426

comments.text:
Yeah, in the U.S light goes straight to green from red. Yellow on only 
comes on to warn you that its going to turn red soon. I think the reason 
might be because everyone drive automatic cars here and no need to let them 
know its about to turn green they just smash the throttle and go.
comments.author: Dineth J

comments.text:
I don't know what these guys are telling you- they are not understanding 
your question. First, our lights are red, yellow, green. We have no orange. 
Second, we do not have the warning system working the same exactly either. 
We have the yellow before red, but we don't have a warning before green 
like they have in Germany. I don't remember if you have that in the UK, as 
I have been there only once. Hope that helps.
comments.author: mrfuriouser

comments.text: We have orange here in the US.
comments.author: Jesse Deptula

comments.text:
No we have the same. I was born in Ireland and moved here recently but I am 
sure we have the basic same traffic things.
comments.author: JL Cannone

comments.text:
would that be a reasonable car to get? or are there many inefficient 
problems with them﻿
comments.author: James Cooper

comments.text:
Mike-G I have a question for you I hope you can give us some advise. We 
have two classic  cars a 1968 Olds 442 that my husband bought while he was 
still over in Vietnam in Sept. 1967. That car has a complete redo from the 
frame up. We also have a restored 1975 GT 85 Corvette. Our question is: How 
do you keep things running correct. We just drained the gas from the 
corvette and it started right up and ran great. We are going to do the same 
thing to the 68 Olds. We just don't have time to drive them all the time. 
How do you store a collector car for a long time?﻿

comments.text:
+nick fernandez the best would be to look out for cars in great condition- 
at the price your ok with (its usually better to but a fully functional car 
then a project car, if you buy a car part by part+ labour its a 100K car 
man!), then look out for part prices... it should give you a good idea! i 
dont know what kind of car your into, but porshe, the 80's ones are 
currently cheap to buy. you can mod em for a good 300 horses, just like my 
'79 camaro, heads, intake, carbs, 300+ horses ready to tear up the asphalt 
with less that 5k in mods!   ...5K i'd actually buy a 383 crate engine and 
dump it on my 700r4 tranny get +400 horses!

comments.text:
Hi im 16 and I am looking at a classic car. I was looking at Camaros 
(1980-1993) and Corvette (1975-1983). which model and year would you 
recommend as an every day car/ first car? I will be driving an old crappy 
car for 2 years until my 18th birthday. I wanted to get a Camaro or 
corvette with a lot of miles and put a ls3 in it.  I want the performance 
but will that increase reliability? And how much do you think I need to gut 
the car out and replace every thing inside and around the engine?﻿

comments.text:
I prefer the Corvette over the Camaro,but that's just my personal opinion. 
You can buy a C3(1978-82) Vette for around 10k. I have a couple and enjoy

30000 KM's and have never had any issues and the other one has about 100000 
KM's and also had no issues with it...Hope this helps! enjoy your ride.

twenty yrs, at once stage had seven cars, all in concours conditions and 
all made to be daily drivers with minimal deviation from original. All

handle any terrain except off road. The guys up there are just wishful 
thinking, have a flatbed ready if you take their classics out daily

comments.text:
I'm sure you wouldn't like it if someone called you stupid and told you 
what you can and can't do to to your cars. So let them be. The cars we own 
today are probably going to end up crushed in junkyards when we're dead. 
Our children probably won't enjoy them as much as us. If your going to keep 
it original and make it a collectible, It will sit in the garage until the 
day of your death. And you never did enjoy it for what it was.
comments.author: Roberto Vasquez

comments.text:
As little as you can get away with..'cos if its sitting in all weather,it 
may not even be worth buying & you won't know this 'till you've pulled it 
apart.But may be what you do is say you want to buy it for next to nothing, 
but you buy it rebuild it&say that when it is up and running, you only run 
it for 1 year, to show/strut it&then sell it & split the difference between 
the rebuild cost ( including pricing your time) & split the real profit 
down the middle.You'll learn a lot .
